p.s: allow me to introduce myself.
My name is Jane Smith, I am 18 years old and currently studying for my Abitur.
I recently found out that you, as an institution, want to take Shakespearean sonnets off the English School Curriculum.
Since I am a student myself, I would like to explain my view on that decision.
Firstly, even though Shakespeare's 400th anniversary is marked in the 21st century, he is more topical than ever.
Shakespearean sonnets deal with timeless topics like love, time and usallyusually poetry itself.
We can often find ourselves in certain situations and project the sonnets onto out daily lives.
Shakespeare understands these topics like no other poet, which is why he is still relevant in our today's society.
He has influenced literature as a whole, especially modern work.
Another striking argument is the language used by Shakespeare.
This might seem contradictory to the argument explained previously, since althoughallthough Shakespeare's work is relevant, his language might seem to be the complete opposite.
But that is what makesShakespeare great.
He has invented and introduced or to noew words, expanded out vocabulary and created pictures on our hands with a few single words.
I see this language barrier as a way of expanding my knowledge and learning to adapt to Shakespeare's writing manners in order to illustrate written art myself.
Last but not least, I find it interesting to deal with sonnets which take place during the Elizabethan time period.
Literature is a form of art which capture certain events or society.
I find it interesting to see how our world has evolved since that time.
Meanwhile it helps to understand happenings of that time as well.
Lastly, why do I think it is important to deal with sonnets in particular?
Shakespearean sonnets are known to be addressed from sonnets one to 126 to a young man, while sonnets 126 to 154 one known to be addressed to a so-called dark lady.
One can truly understand the different lovesShakespeare expresses throughout his sonnets.
It is fascinating how his writing evolves from a dreamy romanticistromanticiest love to a realistic love.
Therefore it helps to find oneself in either sonnet sequence, which again expands Shakespeare's audience.
All in all, I think it would be a tragic flaw to cross outcrossoutShakespeare from the English School Curriculum.
I hope you consider the points presented.
